I dont get why its unitless?  moles/(moles+moles) = mol? Or have i missed something ? :)
its good
is chloride and chlorine the same?
thanks man!
+Jaime Garcia yes

+Eva Kristiansen Unit less because, using the example in the video with 250g NaCl and 1500g H2O,  we have 83.3 mol H2O(solvent) and 4.27mol NaCl(solute). Using the mole fraction equation Solute/(solute+solvent) we get 4.27mol/(83.3mol+4.27mol). If we just do the denominator calculation we get 87.57mol. That is how the moles consolidate, thus numerator 4.27mol divided by denominator 87.57mol, we can cross out the mole.
+Eva Kristiansen mole+mole=mole.  mole/mole=1  hope u got it
Carissa Marie Careras No, chloride is Cl- while chlorine is Cl2.
